title: Fears grow over Greek banks' health
desc: Savers have withdrawn billions of euros from Greek banks over the past week according to reports as talks aimed at resolving the Greek debt crisis stutter.

title: Charleston shooting suspect charged
desc: Charleston church shooting suspect Dylann Roof is charged with nine counts of murder police say.

title: I have never taken drugs says Farah
desc: Double Olympic champion Mo Farah releases a statement saying he has never taken performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Russia fury at Belgium asset seizure
desc: Russia protests to Belgium over its seizure of Russian state assets after a court ordered compensation for shareholders in the now-defunct Yukos oil firm.

title: Danish opposition wins election
desc: Denmark's opposition beats the ruling coalition in the general election with an anti-immigration party becoming the second largest in parliament.

title: Petrobras case nets top businessman
desc: One of Brazil's top businessmen Marcelo Odebrecht is arrested as part of a major investigation into corruption at state-owned oil giant Petrobras.

title: 'Plane stowaway' found dead on roof
desc: A stowaway who is believed to have clung on to a plane falls to his death while another is in hospital.

title: Sisters 'split to cross Syria border'
desc: Three Bradford sisters and their nine children have crossed the border into Syria in two separate groups an IS smuggler tells the BBC.

title: Online reviews 'used as blackmail'
desc: Businesses ambush rivals with fake reviews and customers reportedly use the threat of online criticism to win discounts UK research finds.

title: Tunisian consular staff freed in Libya
desc: Ten Tunisian diplomatic staff who were kidnapped in Libya are freed reportedly in exchange for a Libyan militia commander.

title: Pakistan executions stop for Ramadan
desc: Pakistan's prime minister orders the temporary suspension of the death penalty during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

title: Kapoor 'vagina' sculpture vandalised
desc: Vandals spray-paint a controversial Anish Kapoor sculpture on display in the gardens of France's Palace of Versailles.

title: VIDEO: Church relatives 'only feel love'
desc: The teenage children of one of the victims of the shooting at a church in Charleston say they have forgiven their mother's killer.

title: VIDEO: Volcano spews huge ash cloud
desc: Mount Sinabung on the island of Sumatra is continuing to spew gas and ash high into the air.

title: VIDEO: Monks fight 'threat' to Myanmar pagoda
desc: Monks in Myanmar are fighting plans for development of land close to the Shwedagon Pagoda one of the country's most famous Buddhist landmarks.

title: VIDEO: 'Carpet of crabs' covers US beaches
desc: Hundreds of thousands of tiny crabs have been washing up on Southern California's beaches after warm ocean currents carried them closer to the shoreline than usual.

title: VIDEO: On board the USS Chancellorsville
desc: The BBC's Rupert Wingfield-Hayes steps aboard one of the most powerful missile cruisers in the US Navy the USS Chancellorsville which has arrived in Japan.

title: VIDEO: South Africa CEOs sleep rough for charity
desc: A group of South Africa's top CEOs have slept rough on the streets of Johannesburg to raise money for a local children's charity.

title: VIDEO: The town where yoga is big business
desc: The town of Rishikesh in northern India is often called the yoga capital of the world with a whole industry having built up around the art.

title: VIDEO: Winehouse documentary angers family
desc: A documentary about the life of the late award-winning singer Amy Winehouse has its UK premiere at the Edinburgh International Film Festival.

title: Syria's Druze under threat as conflict spreads
desc: Syria's Druze under threat as conflict spreads

title: Have Israel-US relations reached a new low?
desc: These are turbulent times for the relationship between Israel and its closest ally says Jonathan Marcus.

title: Is there any way Greece can avoid default?
desc: The gulf between Greece and its creditors is both yawningly wide and surprisingly narrow. Does the Greek government needs to be less ambitious in what it seeks from the talks?

title: The women whom science forgot
desc: Many female scientists in the past were not given credit for their achievements - here are just a few of them.

title: The man who can't stop making money
desc: This week-end hundreds of thousands of small investors will be saluting Neil Woodford whose fund has provided an 18% return in its first year

title: VIDEO: Obama mass shootings and gun control
desc: The BBC contrasts President Obama's reactions after mass shootings with the levels of US gun ownership during his terms in office.

title: Lucky escape for motorbike baby
desc: A newborn baby in China survives after hospital motorbike dash.

title: Most kangaroos are 'left-handed'
desc: Scientists report that wild kangaroos tend to favour their left hands in common tasks - the first example of non-human species-wide handedness.

title: VIDEO: BBC World News business headlines
desc: The latest international business headlines from BBC World News.

title: VIDEO: Greek turmoil spurs cash withdrawals
desc: Fears are growing over the health of Greek banks after indications that savers have withdrawn billions of euros in the past week.

title: Facebook drops photo app in Europe
desc: Facebook's photo-synching app Moments will not be launched in Europe because of its use of facial recognition technology.

title: Saucy QR porn code too hot for Heinz
desc: A QR code on a bottle of Heinz ketchup directed browsers to a site that was being used to host porn.

title: Clarkson 'not offered Top Gear job'
desc: The BBC has denied it invited Jeremy Clarkson back as host of Top Gear months after he was axed from the job.

title: BBC success at Monte Carlo TV awards
desc: BBC shows Happy Valley The Missing and Marvellous win multiple awards at the Monte Carlo television awards.

title: DNA reignites ancient skeleton row
desc: DNA tests show an ancient skeleton known as Kennewick Man is related to modern Native Americans - reigniting a debate over whether his bones should be returned to local tribes and reburied.

title: Elephant poaching hotspots identified
desc: Most illegally poached African elephant ivory can be traced back to just two areas of Africa research shows.

title: New anti-malaria compound discovered
desc: Scientists at Dundee University develop an exciting new single-dose malaria drug to combat drug-resistant parasites.

title: Blood chemical predicts brain decline
desc: Scientists discover a chemical in blood that indicates whether people will have declining brain function in the years to come.

title: Vettel top as Hamilton struggles
desc: Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel tops second practice at the Austrian GP with Lewis Hamilton fifth after an error-strewn session.

title: Top seed Halep beaten by Mladenovic
desc: Kristina Mladenovic beats world number three Simona Halep 2-6 6-0 7-6 in the quarter-finals of the Aegon Classic.

title: How did the Turin Shroud get its image?
desc: Some say it's Jesus Christ's burial wrapping others say it's a medieval fake. Either way how does the Turin Shroud come to bear a man's image?

title: The great Moldovan bank robbery
desc: It's a mystery that's thrown Europe's poorest nation into deep crisis - $1bn has vanished from three of Moldova's leading banks much of it passing through UK companies.

title: How Beijing residents are outing smokers
desc: A message board is being used to post photos of smokers defying a citywide ban

title: Prince has 'secret' show for Obamas
desc: White House officials will not say whether pop star Prince performed at a weekend party at the executive residence despite guests posting about it on social media.

title: Row over age of consent in Zimbabwe
desc: Zimbabwe's top public prosecutor questions whether all cases involving sex with girls under 16 should be treated as rape sparking a national row.

title: Thailand confirms first Mers case
desc: Thailand confirms its first case of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) the deadly virus that has killed 24 people in South Korea.

title: Emergency summit called over Greece
desc: Leaders from eurozone nations are to hold an emergency summit on Monday after the latest attempts to resolve the Greek debt crisis failed.

title: Brazil senators flee Venezuela attack
desc: A group of eight Brazilian senators on a visit to Venezuela to meet a jailed opposition leader say they had to flee after their bus was attacked.

title: World's displaced 'hits record high'
desc: The number of people displaced by war conflict or persecution reached a record high of nearly 60 million around the world in 2014 a UN report says.

title: Plans to bring balcony victims home
desc: Arrangements are being made to bring home the bodies of five students who died after a balcony collapsed in California in the United States.

title: Jehovah's Witnesses in abuse payout
desc: A woman who claimed Jehovah's Witness elders failed to protect her from sex abuse carried out by a convicted paedophile wins a £275000 payout.

title: Kerry Dixon jailed over pub assault
desc: Former England and Chelsea footballer Kerry Dixon is jailed for nine months for punching and kicking a man who is said to have called him fatso.

title: Prince Harry ends Army career
desc: Prince Harry's decade-long career with the Army has ended and he will now spend three months in Africa Kensington Palace says.

title: Evans 'not dropped from UKIP role'
desc: UKIP denies Suzanne Evans has been dropped as a party spokeswoman claiming a leaked e-mail suggesting otherwise was sent to the BBC without proper authority.
